answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Hi Angel,
I believe that I have found some documents that might be useful in answering your question. 
To begin, there was a question asked very recently, in the past 18 hours, regarding paperless workflow policies and procedures. Although there is only one response so far, it looks like something worth keeping an eye on.
http://bit.ly/eANlgQ
Additionally, in 2003 there was an article published titled “Agenda Management System Makes Paper Vanish”. This article details the decision of Farmers Branch, Texas to transition from distributing information packets to a paperless system. In assessing the system they have developed, the article ends with helpful benefits and cost-savings. There is also further contact information at the bottom of the article.
http://bit.ly/ejTvjc
Finally, I was able to locate a document that details three different options in going paperless. While it does not give a specific case study example, it gives good background information on paperless practices and the associated benefits and detriments. 
http://bit.ly/hpOfWF
I hope this helps,
Amanda Dodge
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
202-962-3699
adodge@icma.org

answers.author: Tom Crawford
answers.text:
The City of Ann Arbor went paperless about 9 or 10 years ago. I don't recall what system they started with but in the past 5 years we're using a system called Legistar which handles agendas from initiation to agenda packet and interfaces with MS Word as an editor.  The web-based exterior site is not as intuitive as some users would like but overall it has helped greatly to manage the process and publish the agenda.

answers.author: Sam Anselm
answers.text:
Several cities across the country use CivicPlus as their website provider.  One of the "modules" you can purchase is the Agenda Creator module that does just what you describe - department heads or supervisors can create items, upload supporting documents, then send it up through the chain for approval and addition to the meeting agenda.  I'm not sure if you can purchase the module separately from the website package, but it was pretty simple to use if your clerk's office and department heads are internet/email savvy.  Granicus, a company that does streaming of meetings online, also partners with several agenda managment companies.  I went to a presentation a couple of years ago but can't for the life of me remember the name of the company that gave a presentation on their agenda system.  It was impressive, however.  If I can recall the name of the company, I'll follow up.

answers.author: Michael Smith
answers.text:
Angel,
The City of Oklahoma City requested Request for Proposals for an electronic agenda system in early 2007.  The City received 5 proposals and requested demonstrations from 3 of the vendors.  The City selected SIRE Technologies as the best solution for Oklahoma City.  SIRE provided complete customization on all agendas prepared for the City Council, City boards, trusts, and commissions.  SIRE has provided a Federally approved electronic signature process which the other vendors did not provide.  SIRE provides solutions for agendas, records management, voting and information, minutes, agendas to go, etc. that can be purchased separately.  SIRE has an exceptionally responsive customer service division for any questions or issues almost 12 hours a business day.  I would be glad to provide you additional information if requested.  Thanks.
Frances Kersey
City Clerk
The City of Oklahoma City
405.297.2397
frances.kersey@okc.gov

answers.author: Alex Deshuk
answers.text:
A related update - Daystar (Legistar parent company), and Granicus are merging.
Press Release:
Today is an exciting day for Daystar and all of our Legistar clients. Over the past several months, Daystar has been working with Granicus, the leading provider of government transparency, efficiency, and citizen collaboration solutions, on an agreement that would merge our two companies. Today, Granicus and Daystar are proud to announce that this transaction has been completed, and Daystar products are now officially part of the Granicus product portfolio. Because we’re still in the final stages of preparing for a public announcement, we would greatly appreciate if you kept this information internally confidential until May 7, 2011.
We are pleased to share this news and the exciting opportunities it brings to Legistar customers. Over the coming days you can expect not only a continuation of the same great products and services that Daystar has provided without interruption, but you will also have access to an even broader network of technology resources and government peers as part of the Granicus family. Granicus is a world-class company—over 850 government agencies currently rely on its solutions to connect with citizens in meaningful new ways online, over mobile devices, or social networks through video and other emerging technologies. 
We'd like to invite you to attend a live informational webinar to answer any immediate questions you have about the merger and what it means for you:
Webinar: Welcoming Daystar Customers to the Granicus Family
Date/Time: For your convenience we're hosting this webinar twice:
Thursday, April 22 from 10-10:30 AM PT
Wednesday, May 4 from 9-9:30 AM PT
Register Now
Additionally, you can expect a helpful packet of "Need to Know" information about the merger in the mail and personal calls from the Daystar and Granicus team. This is all in an effort to keep your confidence and satisfaction levels high during this exciting transition period. 
Granicus recognizes the exceptional relationship and services that you have received from Daystar. It will share the same determination to make your continued use of Legistar and InSite a success on an ongoing basis without any changes. Granicus also intends to expand on this service and support structure as we more fully integrate our companies and our technologies. 
In closing, I'd like to extend my deep appreciation to all of you for placing your faith in Daystar through the years. As Granicus’ new Vice President of Legislative Services, I'll continue to work with you to ensure your success with Legistar.

author: Angel Smith
text:
We are in the process implementing an electronic agenda management system. I have read the question and responses in regards to utilizing technology to aid in agenda distribution and that provided a great source of information; however, this system would be implemented internally (for city staff). 
Ideally, any staff member who has an agenda item would upload it into the system and the item would go through a series of check points prior to being approved. Once all agenda items are approved they could be moved to the meeting folder available to council. 
This is an attempt to go paperless. Are there any municipalities that currently have a similar system in place or another one that may be of interest? Thanks!
title: Internal Electronic Agenda Management System
